Recently bought one for my partner and she loves it. I'm getting the Nokia 9 if the camera is a big improvement. Having said that, I have a Huawei P9 plus which is not a complete slouch in the camera quality department.

Personally, I can't see the benefit of the bothie capability, but I'm sure avid social media users will tease out the benefits if there are any. Maybe it will take Apple to have the feature before it becomes "magical" lol. 
Stock Android is great if you value prompt updates and getting Android O (and probably P) before most other manufacturers. Stock Android is great to me. Price was fair. We picked it up in Thailand for 19,500 baht which in my native USD conversion is around 585 USD plus we got a bunch of goodies with the deal to include a battery bank. Fairly priced and cheaper than my Huawei P9 plus when I bought it.

Received it today. Some initial impressions.
Great little phone. Seems T-Mobile US still gets wifi-calling for it despite it being an international model (TA-1052). It's also lacking some of the LTE bands of course. I've yet to fully test the telephony capabilities though. Out and about 4g calls do OK... The speaker is plenty loud, like really loud. Loud as in I hear my notifications across the whole house loud.

Build quality is superb. Excellent design and as far as asthetics go one handed use works well and easily for me. I am normally a Lumia 950 XL user and that phone for me is fairly easy to use with one hand. The Nokia 8 is slimmer and about the same height/length which makes it even easier to use and handle. Two total different UIs though, so I really should be comparing it to another Android device in that regard...
The typical Nokia DTtW and Glance screen work as they should and are perfect features for it. Basic Android (or pure Android with no added software overlay or skin) works fast and fluidly on it. It updated to 8.1 as I set it up...I've yet to go even a full day on the device and so far the battery seems as good as expected.
The finger print reader is a bit disappointing though. It seems to inaccurately read my finger sometimes causing me to have to slowly place my print on it or tap the reader a second time in a different position.
Overall no real complaints though.

Pretty much all features of a real Nokia flagship:

title: Who is actually making Nokia phones?

thread.text: From what I read after Microsoft bought / paid, whatever for the Nokia phone division I was under the impression that Nokia no longer manufactured phones, I thought it was part of the agreement with Microsoft that they wouldn't manufacture phones. I thought I read someplace the new Nokia phones were being manufactured by Foxconn, I'm probably mistaken though. Anyone know who is making the current line of Nokia Android phones?
HMD makes Nokia android phones. Sort of like blackberry and TCL now. Here ya go https://www.hmdglobal.com/

HMD develops Nokia phones.
Foxconn (FCI) is actually producing them.
This is well documented.

It's a "cooperation".
- Nokia provides the base technologies. All the patents that belong to Nokia Technologies (NONE was sold to Microsoft by the way) like what was known as ClearBlack or PureView, are provided to HMD by Nokia.
- HMD Global, the Finnish company started unofficially by Nokia and made of ex-Nokia employees, designs and develops the phones. They do the hardware and the tiny bit of software that they add to the stock Android ROM, ie. the camera app.
- Foxconn manufactures and distributes the phones, pretty much like they do for Apple.
